title: Bankruptcy chapter 7. Exempt from means test because majority Non-consumer debts. Will my personal income matter at all?
question: Example: If I owe 2 million in business debt and only 100k in personal debt, I should be exempt from the Means Test, correct? My wife too?
question_tags: Business debt,Chapter 7 bankruptcy for businesses,Chapter 13 bankruptcy for businesses,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Eligibility for filing chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Bankruptcy estate,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Secured debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Chapter 13 bankruptcy eligibility,Business
answers: I have filed several chapter 7 bankruptcy cases where the client made over the means test limits but where more than 50% of the unsecured debt was business debt with no problem, In your case it helps that the that you debt exceeds the chapter 13 debt limits for unsecured and secured debt (currently $383,175 and $1,149,525 respectively). I caution you that the classification of debt as consumer or business can sometimes be tricky. Consult with an experienced attorney.

There is a split of authority among federal districts/bankruptcy courts on this issue. Will be wise to explore your options with experienced counsel and plan for alternatives, including possibility ( even if slim...) of chapter 7 trustee raising the issue in the form of motion to convert or dismiss regarding bad faith and/or totality of circumstances.

The means test is not applicable to debtors with primarily business debts. However, your personal residence mortgage probably will be on the personal side, not the business side. If you have rentals and your in the business, then those would lean towards the business side. A vacation home would lean towards the personal side. Like the other attorneys mentioned, you should meet with an attorney to make sure your debts are properly categorized.
You still have to pass the "good faith" smell test. See more information at the link below. Hope this perspective helps!

First, you are right..Means test wont matter.

Second, your debt exceeds the ch 13 limits to qualify. Thus, only ch 7 and ch 11 remain and a ch 11 is expensive. I have seen cases where they have argued against you being in a ch 7 where your income is too high even though you cannot do a ch 13! But I would always take the chance to try and do it anyway as you can always do a ch 11 but want to avoid so if possible!

Enjoy your fresh start also if you do file a ch 7 and obtain that discharge.. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what. Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can. You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

Where I practice, if you have primarily business debt, you can file a Chapter 7 regardless of your income and expenses. My understanding is that this is not universal, and counsel is correct that the totalities of circumstances test may still come into play regarding Chapter 7 eligibility. I highly recommend consulting with a local, experienced bankruptcy attorney to see how the trustees and US Trustee view this issue in your district.

You are basically correct. The means test only applies in consumer cases, so where the majority of your debt is business debt it does not apply. The court and the United States Trustee will, however, use the "totality of the circumstances" test to determine whether you are eligible for Chapter 7. It would certainly be a good idea to consult with a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney to discuss how this test would impact your filing.
